title: 108_hr1276
content: The "American Dream Downpayment Act" is also known as the Downpayment Assistance Initiative under the HOME Program, amending the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act to provide downpayment assistance. The Secretary may grant assistance to low-income families for homeownership through downpayment assistance for single-family housing. Eligible families can receive help to acquire a principal residence. For the purposes of this title, 'downpayment assistance' refers to aid for low-income, first-time homebuyers to acquire a principal residence, including uniformed employees and teachers. The downpayment assistance program includes uniformed employees (such as policemen, firemen, and sanitation workers) or teachers from the participating jurisdiction with a qualifying income. The downpayment assistance program is available for families with an income not exceeding 115 percent of the median income of the area. The downpayment assistance program is available for larger families with an income limit of 115 percent of the median income of the area, or 150 percent in high housing cost areas determined by the Secretary. The median income of the area is used to determine eligibility for grants under the housing strategy. This includes a plan for targeted outreach to residents of public housing and other assisted families. The grant amounts are to be used for downpayment assistance for residents of public housing, trailer parks, and manufactured housing. Actions will be taken to ensure the suitability of families for homeownership. The Secretary will allocate assistance amounts based on a formula considering jurisdictions' need and commitment to homebuyer assistance. This includes ensuring families are suitable for homeownership. The Secretary will allocate assistance based on a formula that considers a jurisdiction's prior commitment to homebuyer assistance, including amounts from various programs and factors deemed appropriate. The Secretary will allocate assistance based on a formula that considers a jurisdiction's prior commitment to homebuyer assistance, including amounts from various programs and factors deemed appropriate. If any allocated amounts become available for reallocation, they will be redistributed to other participating jurisdictions according to the established formula, with exceptions for local jurisdictions in states that did not receive their allocation. According to the formula established in subsection (d), funds allocated under this section will be reallocated to the State if a local participating jurisdiction in a participating State did not receive their allocation. Grants under this section are not subject to the provisions of this title, except for those outlined in title I, section 215(b). Grants under this section are subject to provisions of title I, sections 215(b), 218, 219, 221, 223, 224, and 226(a) of this title, and subtitle F. References to funds under subtitle A are considered to refer to amounts for assistance under this section. In paragraph (2), references to funds under subtitle A are considered to refer to amounts for assistance under this section. Administrative and planning costs can be covered using funds under subtitle A, despite the restrictions in section 212(c). Under subsection (d) or (e) of this section, a participating jurisdiction may use funds for administrative and planning costs. Authorization of $200,000,000 for fiscal years 2004 and 2005 is provided for carrying out this section. Relocation and downpayment assistance are covered under Subtitle F of the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act. Authorization of $200,000,000 for fiscal years 2004 and 2005 is provided for carrying out relocation and downpayment assistance under Subtitle F of the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act. The Uniform Relocation Assistance and Real Property Acquisition Policies Act of 1970 does not apply to downpayment assistance under this title. Passed by the House of Representatives on October 1, 2003.
